                                                     Department Directory                                                                                                              Home / Academics / Master of Social Work / Curriculum                                                               Field Learning                                                                                                                                                                                 Field learning lies at the heart of social work education and your development as a social worker. Within the context of the field placement experience, and aligned practice courses, you will have the opportunity to integrate theory and practice. Because the Silver School of Social Work has developed unique partnerships with over 600 public and nonprofit agencies throughout the tri-state area, our placement sites are varied, of high quality, and offer students a rich learning environment. No school devotes as much effort to matching students with appropriate field learning opportunities.   Field learning will immerse you in the extraordinary range of human and social problems that lead clients to reach out for help. It will provide you the opportunity to develop skills and appreciate the realities of coping with complex problems in the context of specific service-delivery systems.   You will be trained to work with a wide range of populations in diverse practice settings. With an emphasis on training for social work practice that promotes social and economic justice, your field education will advance your learning as a relationship-centered, reflective practitioner, preparing you for work with individuals, groups, families, and communities.   For MSW students, in your first, or professional foundation, year, the primary goal of field learning is to provide a foundation of social work practice skills within a generalist perspective. (See foundation year learning objectives in the MSW Student Manual .)     In the second, or advanced concentration, year, MSW students focus their graduate education on specific aspects of social work within specific practice systems (fields of practice) along with their professional development and growth. The faculty advisor, in the capacity of educational consultant, assists students with the development of educational goals and objectives for the advanced concentration year. (See advanced concentration year learning objectives for in the MSW Student Manual .)     Focused Learning Opportunities   The School continues to expand its range of specialized initiatives for students in their advanced concentration year. Students who select to participate in focused learning opportunities are recommended to take specific courses and required colloquia designed to provide curricular support for specialized placements. The following focused learning opportunities are available to students:     Social Work Practice with Children and Families     Social Work Practice with Adolescents in Schools     Social Work Practice with Substance Abuse and Co-Occurring Disorders     Social Work Practice: Zelda Foster Studies in Palliative and End-of-Life Care     Social Work Practice: Evidence-Based Mental Health Practice for Adults with Severe Mental Illness     Social Work Practice: Macro/Micro Practice in Organizations   Social Work Practice : Integrated Youth Behavioral Health Project   Social Work Practice: Integrated Health Care with Adults       See the Fields of Practice and Focused Learning Opportunities Manual for full descriptions and requirements. Field Learning Calendars                                                             Department Directory                                                                                                              Home / Academics / Master of Social Work / Curriculum / Field Learning                                                       Field Learning Calendars                                                                                                                                                                                 The field learning calendars differ from the academic calendar because they reflect the importance of continuity of care for clients and ensure that students meet the MSW and undergraduate program required hours. Community Partnerships                                                             Student Manuals and Forms                                                             Field Learning Calendars                                                             Department Directory                                                                                                              Home / Academics / Master of Social Work / Curriculum                                                               Field Learning                                                                                                                                                                                 Field learning lies at the heart of social work education and your development as a social worker. Within the context of the field placement experience, and aligned practice courses, you will have the opportunity to integrate theory and practice. Because the Silver School of Social Work has developed unique partnerships with over 600 public and nonprofit agencies throughout the tri-state area, our placement sites are varied, of high quality, and offer students a rich learning environment. No school devotes as much effort to matching students with appropriate field learning opportunities.   Field learning will immerse you in the extraordinary range of human and social problems that lead clients to reach out for help. It will provide you the opportunity to develop skills and appreciate the realities of coping with complex problems in the context of specific service-delivery systems.   You will be trained to work with a wide range of populations in diverse practice settings. With an emphasis on training for social work practice that promotes social and economic justice, your field education will advance your learning as a relationship-centered, reflective practitioner, preparing you for work with individuals, groups, families, and communities.   For MSW students, in your first, or professional foundation, year, the primary goal of field learning is to provide a foundation of social work practice skills within a generalist perspective. (See foundation year learning objectives in the MSW Student Manual .)     In the second, or advanced concentration, year, MSW students focus their graduate education on specific aspects of social work within specific practice systems (fields of practice) along with their professional development and growth. The faculty advisor, in the capacity of educational consultant, assists students with the development of educational goals and objectives for the advanced concentration year. (See advanced concentration year learning objectives for in the MSW Student Manual .)     Focused Learning Opportunities   The School continues to expand its range of specialized initiatives for students in their advanced concentration year. Students who select to participate in focused learning opportunities are recommended to take specific courses and required colloquia designed to provide curricular support for specialized placements. The following focused learning opportunities are available to students:     Social Work Practice with Children and Families     Social Work Practice with Adolescents in Schools     Social Work Practice with Substance Abuse and Co-Occurring Disorders     Social Work Practice: Zelda Foster Studies in Palliative and End-of-Life Care     Social Work Practice: Evidence-Based Mental Health Practice for Adults with Severe Mental Illness     Social Work Practice: Macro/Micro Practice in Organizations   Social Work Practice : Integrated Youth Behavioral Health Project   Social Work Practice: Integrated Health Care with Adults       See the Fields of Practice and Focused Learning Opportunities Manual for full descriptions and requirements.                                                                                                                                                     Student Manuals   The purpose of the Manuals is to acquaint you with the School's procedures and requirements so that you can succeed in your studies. Consult the School's web site and your email for updates. If required, please modify your information on ‘Albert’. These updates will automatically update our Field Learning database. For assistance please call the Office of Field Learning and Community Partnerships at (212) 998-5920.     Employment based field learning applications and guidelines:     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) / 900 Hours Application (PDF)     Extended One Year Residence (OYR) Guidelines (PDF     Employment based (Non-OYR) / 600 Hours Application (PDF)     Employment based (Non-OYR) Guidelines (PDF)       Student Evaluation Forms   The assessment of students in field is based upon the CSWE Core Competencies. The field instructor, in collaboration with the student, works to evaluate the student’s progress over the course of the year.   Initial Educational Statement   The Initial Educational Statement should be completed by the field instructor and student collaboratively. Part I, the Orientation and Field Instruction Plan, should be completed within the first two weeks of placement. Part II provides a baseline assessment of the student’s skill level, establishes the learning plan for the remainder of the semester, and provides an initial indication of the grade level of the student’s performance in the early stages of placement. Part II should be completed in the 7th week of field placement.     Undergraduate Senior Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Professional Foundation Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement (PDF)     Advanced Concentration Initial Educational Statement / Micro Macro Practice (PDF)     Mid-Year Evaluation   The Mid-Year Evaluation is completed at the end of the first semester of either the foundation year or the advanced concentration year and after the student has finished the 300 hours required for field instruction. The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the evaluation as a major component of assigning a grade for Field Instruction. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation).   Final Evaluation   This evaluation is completed at the end of the second semester of either the foundation or advanced concentration placement, after the student has finished the additional 300 hours required for Field Instruction (and a total of 600 hours for each of the foundation and advanced concentration placements). The field instructor completes the evaluation in collaboration with the student, and the evaluation signed by both. The faculty advisor reviews the Final Evaluation as a major component of the process of assigning a grade for Field Instruction II or IV. (The faculty advisor will not be able to give a grade without a completed evaluation.) The field instructor and student should both sign the evaluation form. The evaluation can be scanned and emailed to field.learning@nyu.edu or and faxed to (212) 995-4533.
